column4: I hear your frustration, and I've had plenty of grub/grub2 headaches as well, but I believe their stated reasons for the grub->grub2 migration are compelling.
I guess I have to keep faith and learn again, you see, a transition from an expert to a newbie is traumatizing. We demand counselling to accompany the Grub2 HOWTO
traumatizing, for sure
are you looking for a hand translating your menu.lst to the grub.cfg form?
I need to customize my grub2 bootloader
I want to have for example a line that has only "LINUX" and another line with "WINDOWS"
I dont need all the fuss about 2.6.***... appearing
the fuss over kernel versions is there so you can tell apart which kernel you're starting. kernel updates sometimes patch nasty bugs, and sometimes introduce regressions.
would you want to remove all the single-user mode boot menu items too?
I know but for a family friendly computer those need to be hidden, the children can hardly sleep by those kernel versions
oh i see
yes ofcourse, as well as that useless memtest thing
you can strip down your boot menu, but afaik that would mean you'd have to boot manually at the grub2 cmd prompt if something went haywire and you needed to start in maintenance mode; is that ok?
that is NOT ok. So, in simple English, there is no way to customise the entries on the GRUB2 boot loader menu?
yes you can customize, but it's a process one doesn't undertake so lightly
I rest my case. adalal, you are right. there is no straightforward way to edit the entries
that would beg the question of what one considers as straightforward, within the field of configuring things on Unix-like systems in general
ok I withdraw my statement about straightforwardness, but IT CANNOT BE DONE!!
something could be done, but it might not suit your wishes for ease of use, maintainability and so forth
that file begs you with capital letters that you should not attempt editing it
I know, but nothing is done yet
I think the caps are to scare off people who are not so well informed; it can be edited, I do it often; I just do it knowing it's at my own risk

elzoog, I remember another GUI that claimed to make things easy for GRUB legacy, it did more harm than good, GRUB2 needs to be friendly with or without a GUI frontend. As this is a critical part of the whole OS, there should not be any excuses about this. otherwise the installation process should always ask you to choose the grub version you want to use
